cn.edu.xjtu.se.jackq

Class ConnectFour

  • java.lang.Object
    • cn.edu.xjtu.se.jackq.ConnectFour
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConnectFourGUI

    public class ConnectFour
extends java.lang.Object
    Connect four is a two-player board game in which the players alternately drop colored disks into a seven-column, six-row vertically suspended grid. In this implementation, there are two colors which are yellow and red representing two players. The game board stored in a two-dimensional array of integers. For determining whether one of the players have achieved the goal of the game that is have four same colored disks connected, another utility is used in this package (PatternRecognition.isConsecutiveFour(int[][]) ).

    To use this game class, one way is initialize an instance and then invoke the start() method to run this game in console. Another method is to manage game logic in other environment by invoking dropDisk(int, int), isFill(), isFinish() etc.. To access inner state of the game in order to gain more flexibility, you can extend this class as a foundation of higher level implementation. An example can found in this package as ConnectFourGUI, which implements an swing user interface for this game.

    Author:
    Jack Q (qiaobo@outlook.com)
    See Also:
    ConnectFourGUI, PatternRecognition.isConsecutiveFour(int[][])

      • RED

        protected static final int RED
        a magic number representing red color for disk and player. To use this name at string output, refer to getColorName(int)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • YELLOW

        protected static final int YELLOW
        a magic number representing yellow color for disk and player. To use this name at string output, refer to getColorName(int)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • columnDiskCount

        protected final int[] columnDiskCount
        integer array storing the current number of disks in a specific column.

        It should be kept consistency with values stored in gameBoard, which means when updating the content of game board, this filed should also be updated.

        This filed is mainly used to simplify the state judgment process, since in this game, most of actions are merely related with the number of disks in a column such as determining whether a column is filled and whether the game board is filled.

      • gameBoard

        protected final int[][] gameBoard
        two-dimensional array of integers which stores current state of the game.

        This integers in this field will be initialized to unique negative integer to satisfied the requirement of ruled in PatternRecognition.isConsecutiveFour(int[][]). When checking whether a specific position on game board is null or has a disk in RED or YELLOW, use isNullPosition(int).

    • Constructor Detail

      • ConnectFour

        public ConnectFour()
        Initial game board (gameBoard) and column disk count (columnDiskCount).

    • Method Detail

      • printGame

        public void printGame()
        Print the current state of game to System.out.

        In this method, the RED is represented as character 'R' , the YELLOW is represented as character 'Y' and the null position is represented as character ' '. There will be an horizontal line at the bottom of the output, which is consisted of character '-'.

      • canDropDisk

        public boolean canDropDisk(int column)
        determine whether a column can add/drop more disks.
        Parameters:
        column - the column number to determine (indexed from 0)
        Returns:
        true if the column has not be filled

      • dropDisk

        public int dropDisk(int color,
                    int column)
        add/drop a disk with specific color to a column in gameBoard

        This method will automatically update the columnDiskCount

        Parameters:
        color - the color of the disk to be added/dropped.
        column - the index of column to add/drop a disk.
        Returns:
        the number of disks in the column after dropping this disk, which is also the index of the last disk counted form bottom.

      • isFill

        public boolean isFill()
        determine whether the game board is filled.

        Since this game cannot guarantee a winner will be found before the game board is fully filled with disks, check this state before dropping another disk instead of only check for isFinish().

        This method determine the state by checking the values stored in columnDiskCount, which means it depends on the consistency between columnDiskCount and gameBoard.

        Returns:
        true if the game board is filled with disks

      • isFinish

        public boolean isFinish()
        determine whether the game is finished based on the game board. This method use PatternRecognition.isConsecutiveFour(int[][]) to determine the result.
        Returns:
        true if there has four consecutive disks in same color
        See Also:
        PatternRecognition.isConsecutiveFour(int[][])

      • isNullPosition

        public boolean isNullPosition(int gameBoardState)

      • start

        public void start()
        run the current game based on System.in and System.out, then execute the game logic.

        The program prompts two players to drop a RED or YELLOW disk alternately. Whenever a disk is dropped, the program re-displays the board on the console and determines the status of the game (win, draw, or continue).

      • getColorName

        public java.lang.String getColorName(int color)
        get the String representation of the color.
        Parameters:
        color - the color to be converted
        Returns:
        the String representation of the color

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        entry point for start an new game
        Parameters:
        args - command line parameters
